to stop hoping for something or trying to do something because you no longer feel confident
to fall in love with somebody/something

idioms.text: a man/woman after your own heart
idioms.sense: a man/woman who likes the same things or has the same opinions as you

idioms.text: not have the heart (to do something)
idioms.sense: to be unable to do something because you know that it will make somebody sad or upset

idioms.text: off by heart (British English) (also by heart British and North American English)
idioms.sense: using only your memory
examples: She's learnt the whole speech off by heart.
I've seen the show so often I know all the songs by heart.

idioms.text: out of the goodness of your heart
idioms.sense: because of kind feelings, without thinking about what advantage there will be for you
examples: You're not telling me he offered to lend you the money out of the goodness of his heart?

idioms.text: pour out/open your heart to somebody
idioms.sense: to tell somebody all your problems, feelings, etc.
examples: Finally, he broke down in tears and poured out his heart to her.

idioms.text: set your heart on something | have your heart set on something
idioms.sense: to want something very much
examples: They’ve set their heart on a house in the country.

idioms.sense: very unhappy or disappointed
to cry noisily for a long time because you are very sad
examples: She flung herself at his chest and sobbed her heart out.

idioms.sense: to make somebody fall in love with you

idioms.text: strike fear, etc. into somebody/sb’s heart
idioms.sense: to make somebody be afraid, etc.
examples: The sound of gunfire struck fear into the hearts of the villagers.

idioms.sense: to feel more positive about something, especially when you thought that you had no chance of achieving something
examples: The government can take heart from the latest opinion polls.

idioms.sense: to be very upset by something that somebody says or does
examples: You shouldn’t take everything he says to heart.

idioms.text: tear at your heart | tear your heart out
idioms.sense: to strongly affect you in an emotional way

idioms.text: tear/rip the heart out of something
idioms.sense: to destroy the most important part or aspect of something
examples: Closing the factory tore the heart out of the community.

idioms.sense: as much as you want
examples: a supervised play area where children can run around to their heart’s content

idioms.sense: to make somebody feel happy or sympathetic
examples: Doesn’t that story just warm the cockles of your heart?

idioms.sense: the way to make somebody like or love you
examples: The way to a man's heart is through his stomach (= by giving him good food).

idioms.text: wear your heart on your sleeve
idioms.sense: to allow your feelings to be seen by other people
examples: He’s not one to wear his heart on his sleeve.

idioms.text: what the eye doesn’t see (the heart doesn’t grieve over)
idioms.sense: if a person does not know about something that they would normally think was bad, then it cannot hurt them
examples: What does it matter if I use his flat while he’s away? What the eye doesn’t see…!

idioms.sense: to make somebody love you

idioms.text: with all your heart/your whole heart
idioms.sense: completely
examples: I hope with all my heart that things work out for you.
I wish you well with all my heart.

idioms.sense: thinking and behaving like a young person even when you are old
examples: My father is 76 but he’s still young at heart.
He's over 70, but he's young at heart.

senses.text: the part of the body at the end of the arm, including the fingers and thumb
examples: Ian placed a hand on her shoulder.
Keep both hands on the steering wheel at all times.
She had a large diamond on the ring finger of her left hand.
in your hand He was holding a large mug of coffee in his right hand.
Put your hand up if you know the answer.
She was on (her) hands and knees (= crawling on the floor) looking for an earring.
Couples strolled past holding hands.
She introduced us and we shook hands.
Give me your hand (= hold my hand) while we cross the road.
The crowd threw up their hands (= lifted them into the air) in dismay.
He killed the snake with his bare hands (= using only his hands).
a hand gesture/signal
a hand towel (= a small towel for drying your hands on)
a hand drill (= one that is used by turning a handle rather than powered by electricity)
I felt the bag to see what was in it.
She fingered the silk delicately.
Handle the fruit with care.
She rubbed her eyes wearily.
The cat loves being stroked.
He patted my arm and told me not to worry.
Someone was tapping lightly at the door.
I took his hand and squeezed it.
I grabbed his arm to stop myself from falling.
She snatched the letter out of my hand.
Her hands were clasped behind her head.
The child was clutching a doll in her hand.

Beth grasped the rope with both hands.
Clive ran a hand through his hair.
Eager hands reached out to help him.
He beat his hands on the steering wheel in frustration.
He clutched the cane in his clammy hand.
He grabbed my hand and motioned for me to follow him.
He had his hands clasped behind his head.
He lifted his hand to her face.
He offered a limp hand to shake.
He rubbed his hands together in satisfaction.
He sat with his head in his hands.
He shook Blake's hand as if they were long lost friends.
He slid his hands into his pockets.
He wiped his greasy hands on the front of his overalls.
Her busy hands had transformed the tiny room into a work of art.
Her hand flew to her mouth. ‘Oh no!’
Her hand ran over the surface, feeling the different textures.
Her hand shook as she lifted the glass to her lips.
His hand brushed against hers.
His hands clawed at the muddy earth.
His hands cupped her face.
Muriel's hand crept to her neck to hold her pearls.
Operate the gears with your left hand.
She filled our glasses with a generous hand.
She folds her hands in prayer.
She gestured to the window with an open hand.
She had a piece of paper in her hand.
She had large rings on both hands.
She held on to my hand as I tried to leave.
She held up her hand in farewell.
She pressed his hand. ‘I know, ’ she said softly.
She put her hands to her cheeks in embarrassment.
She shivered, rubbing her hands together fiercely.
She shrugged and spread her hands. ‘That's all I can tell you.’
She smiled and extended a hand in welcome.
She stood in the doorway, hands on hips.
She stood up and went over to him, her hands outstretched.
She studied the object in the palm of her hand.
Slowly Ruth withdrew her hand from his.
The rocks looked like they had been shaped by human hands.
We were all clapping our hands in time to the music.
With his free hand he took hold of the knife.
With a practised hand he motioned a waiter to bring a fresh pot of coffee.
A surgeon needs a good eye and a steady hand.
There's plenty of work for willing hands
Purée with a hand blender or food processor.
a one-handed catch
left-handed scissors (= intended to be held in your left hand)
The neighbours are always willing to lend a hand.
hand with something Let me give you a hand with those bags (= help you to carry them).
Do you need a hand with those invoices?
Early reports suggest the hand of rebel forces in the bombings.
Several of his colleagues had a hand in his downfall.
This appointment was an attempt to strengthen her hand in policy discussions.
The farmer would bring in hired hands to help him harvest the crop.
All hands on deck!
hand-painted pottery
hand-knitted
This item should be hand-washed.
Mail for hand delivery is put in a separate tray.
to be dealt a good/bad hand
(figurative) She felt that life had dealt her a bad hand.
I'll have to leave after this hand.
Who dealt the last hand?
The fabric was painted by hand.
Delicate clothes should be washed by hand.
We can apply the power of computational tools in solving mathematical problems that cannot be solved by hand.
They walked through the park hand in hand.
Poverty and poor health often go hand in hand.
Hands up all those who want to go swimming.
We managed to redecorate the house and still have some savings in hand.
She completed the first part of the exam with over an hour in hand.
Don’t worry about the travel arrangements—everything is in hand.
Please confine your comments to the topic in hand.
Education has been reluctant to join hands with business.
Unemployment is getting out of hand.
All our suggestions were dismissed out of hand.

idioms.text: all hands on deck (also all hands to the pump)
idioms.sense: everyone helps or must help, especially in a difficult situation
examples: There are 30 people coming to dinner tonight, so it's all hands on deck.

idioms.sense: close to you in time or distance
examples: Help was at hand.
The property is ideally located with all local amenities close at hand.

idioms.text: at the hands of somebody | at somebody’s hands
idioms.sense: if you experience something at the hands of somebody, they are the cause of it
examples: They suffered years of repression at the hands of the old regime.

idioms.sense: to show skill at making or doing things with your hands
to tie somebody’s hands and feet together so that they cannot move or escapeto prevent somebody from doing what they want by creating rules, limits, etc.

idioms.text: a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush
idioms.sense: it is better to keep something that you already have than to risk losing it by trying to get much more

idioms.text: bite the hand that feeds you
idioms.sense: to harm somebody who has helped you or supported you
by a person rather than a machineif a letter is delivered by hand, it is delivered by the person who wrote it, or somebody who is sent by them, rather than by post
examples: The fabric was painted by hand.
Delicate clothes should be washed by hand.
We can apply the power of computational tools in solving mathematical problems that cannot be solved by hand.

idioms.sense: if you pay for goods and services cash in hand, you pay in cash, especially so that the person being paid can avoid paying tax on the amount
examples: a cash-in-hand payment of £20

idioms.sense: to pass to a different owner
examples: The house has changed hands several times.

idioms.sense: near; in a place where somebody/something can be reached easily
examples: There are good cafes and a restaurant close at hand.

idioms.sense: an influence that controls or limits something
examples: We need to free business from the dead hand of bureaucracy.

idioms.text: the devil makes work for idle hands
idioms.sense: people who do not have enough to do often start to do wrong
examples: She blamed the crimes on the local jobless teenagers. ‘The devil makes work for idle hands,’ she would say.

idioms.sense: to trust somebody and be willing to do what they say
examples: She'll have them eating out of her hand in no time.

idioms.text: fall into somebody’s hands/the hands of somebody
idioms.sense: to become controlled by somebody
examples: The town fell into enemy hands.
We don't want this document falling into the wrong hands.
After the war, the hotel fell into the hands of an American consortium.

idioms.sense: strong control or discipline
examples: Those children need a firm hand to make them behave.

idioms.sense: by experiencing, seeing, etc. something yourself rather than being told about it by somebody else
examples: The President visited the area to see the devastation at first hand.

idioms.sense: to bring or hold your hands together
examples: She kept her hands folded in her lap.

idioms.sense: to make somebody do something that they do not want to do or make them do it sooner than they had intended
examples: They decided to strike to force the management’s hand.

idioms.text: gain, get, have, etc. the upper hand
idioms.sense: to get an advantage over somebody so that you are in control of a particular situation
to do physical work
examples: He's not frightened of getting his hands dirty.

idioms.text: get, have, etc. a free hand
idioms.sense: to get, have, etc. the opportunity to do what you want to do and to make your own decisions
examples: I was given a free hand in designing the syllabus.

idioms.sense: to show your approval of somebody by clapping your hands; to be applauded in this way
examples: Ladies and gentlemen, let’s give a big hand to our special guests tonight.

idioms.sense: to help somebody

idioms.text: go cap in hand (to somebody) (especially British English) (North American English usually go hat in hand)
idioms.sense: to ask somebody for something, especially money, in a very polite way that makes you seem less important
examples: There’s no way he’ll go cap in hand to his brother.

idioms.sense: permission to marry somebody, especially a woman
examples: He asked the general for his daughter's hand in marriage.

idioms.sense: working closely with somebody, especially in a secret and/or illegal way
if two people are hand in hand, they are holding each other’s handif two things go hand in hand, they are closely connected and one thing causes the other
examples: They walked through the park hand in hand.
Poverty and poor health often go hand in hand.

idioms.sense: easily and without any doubt
examples: They won hands down.
It is hands down the best movie this year.

idioms.sense: used to tell somebody not to touch something/somebody
examples: Get your hands off my wife!
Hey, hands off! That's my drink!
She warned her brother to keep his hands off her bag.

idioms.sense: used to tell a group of people to raise one hand in the air if they know the answer to a question, etc.used by somebody who is threatening people with a gun to tell them to raise both hands in the air
examples: Hands up all those who want to go swimming.

idioms.text: have somebody’s blood on your hands
idioms.sense: to be responsible for somebody’s death
examples: a dictator with the blood of thousands on his hands

idioms.sense: to be very busy or too busy to do something else
examples: She certainly has her hands full with four kids in the house.

idioms.sense: to be unable to do what you want to do because of rules, promises, etc.
examples: I really wish I could help but my hands are tied.

idioms.text: have somebody in the palm of your hand
idioms.sense: to have complete control or influence over somebody
examples: Even before he plays a note, he has the audience in the palm of his hand.

idioms.text: have time on your hands | have time to kill
idioms.sense: to have nothing to do or not be busy

idioms.text: have/hold, etc. the whip hand (over somebody/something)
idioms.sense: to be in a position where you have power or control over somebody/something
examples: She had the whip hand and it was useless to resist.

idioms.sense: a way of doing something or of treating people that is much stronger and less sensitive than it needs to be
examples: the heavy hand of management

idioms.sense: to give somebody support in a difficult situation
examples: Do you want me to come along and hold your hand?

idioms.sense: to admit that you have made a mistake or are responsible for something bad
examples: I have to hold my hands up and admit that some of the problems have been all my own fault.
The solicitor confirmed that his clients were holding their hands up to the offences.

idioms.text: in somebody’s capable, safe, etc. hands
idioms.sense: being taken care of or dealt with by somebody that you think you can rely on
examples: Can I leave these queries in your capable hands?
He retired feeling confident that his company was in safe hands.

idioms.sense: if you have time or money in hand, it is left and available to be usedif you have a particular situation in hand, you are in control of itthe job, question, etc. in hand is the one that you are dealing withif somebody works a week, month, etc. in hand, they are paid for the work a week, etc. after they have completed it
examples: We managed to redecorate the house and still have some savings in hand.
She completed the first part of the exam with over an hour in hand.
Don’t worry about the travel arrangements—everything is in hand.
Please confine your comments to the topic in hand.

idioms.text: in the hands of somebody | in somebody’s hands
idioms.sense: being taken care of or controlled by somebody
examples: The matter is now in the hands of my lawyer.
At that time, the castle was in enemy hands.

idioms.text: in safe hands | in the safe hands of somebody
idioms.sense: being taken care of well by somebody
examples: I've left the kids in safe hands—with my parents.
Their problem was in the safe hands of the experts.

idioms.text: an iron fist/hand (in a velvet glove)
idioms.sense: if you use the words an iron fist/hand when describing the way that somebody behaves, you mean that they treat people severely. This treatment may be hidden behind a kind appearance (the velvet glove).
examples: They promised that the army would strike with an iron fist at any resistance.
The iron hand in the velvet glove approach seems to work best with this age group.

idioms.text: I’ve only got one pair of hands
idioms.sense: used to say that you are too busy to do anything else
if two people join hands, they hold each other’s handsto work together in doing something
examples: Education has been reluctant to join hands with business.

idioms.sense: to occasionally do something that you used to do a lot so that you do not lose your skill at it
examples: She retired last year but still teaches the odd class to keep her hand in.

idioms.text: know somebody/something inside out | know somebody/something like the back of your hand
idioms.sense: to be very familiar with somebody/something
examples: This is where I grew up. I know this area like the back of my hand.

idioms.sense: to catch somebody that you are annoyed with
examples: Wait till I get my hands on him!

idioms.sense: to find or get something
examples: I know their address is here somewhere, but I can't lay my hands on it right now.
I desperately need to get my hands on some money by Monday.

idioms.sense: to spend all the money you earn on basic needs such as food without being able to save any money
to make/lose money very fast and in large quantities
used to say that a job is made easier if a lot of people help
to do no work
examples: She hasn't done a hand's turn all week.

idioms.text: not lift/raise a finger/hand (to do something)
idioms.sense: to do nothing to help somebody
examples: The children never lift a finger to help around the house.

idioms.sense: to hold out your hand for somebody to shake
no longer your responsibility
on both/all sides; in both/all directions
examples: Mist curled from the water on either hand.

idioms.sense: available, especially to help
examples: The emergency services were on hand with medical advice.

idioms.sense: if you have somebody/something on your hands, you are responsible for or have to deal with them/it
examples: Let me take care of the invitations—you've enough on your hands with the caterers.
They’ll have a fight on their hands if they want to close down the school.

idioms.text: (on the one hand…) on the other (hand)…
idioms.sense: used to introduce different points of view, ideas, etc., especially when they are opposites
examples: On the one hand they'd love to have kids, but on the other, they don't want to give up their freedom.
This survey highlights a number of differences in the way that teenage boys and girls in the UK spend their free time.
One of the main differences between the girls and the boys who took part in the research was the way in which they use the internet.
Unlike the girls, who use the internet mainly to keep in touch with friends, the boys questioned in this survey tend to use the internet for playing computer games.
The girls differ from the boys in that they tend to spend more time keeping in touch with friends on the phone or on social networking websites.
Compared to the boys, the girls spend much more time chatting to friends on the phone.
On average the girls spend four hours a week chatting to friends on the phone. In contrast, very few of the boys spend more than five minutes a day talking to their friends in this way.
The boys prefer competitive sports and computer games, whereas/while the girls seem to enjoy more cooperative activities, such as shopping with friends.
When the girls go shopping, they mainly buy clothes and cosmetics. The boys, on the other hand, tend to purchase computer games or gadgets.

idioms.sense: difficult or impossible to controlif you reject, etc. something out of hand, you do so immediately without thinking about it fully or listening to other people’s arguments
examples: Unemployment is getting out of hand.
All our suggestions were dismissed out of hand.

idioms.sense: no longer your responsibility
examples: I'm afraid the matter is now out of my hands.

idioms.sense: to fail to achieve success by judging your position to be stronger than it really is
a person who can do, or is doing, a job
examples: We need an extra pair of hands if we're going to finish on time.

idioms.sense: to do exactly what an enemy, opponent, etc. wants so that they gain the advantage in a particular situation
examples: If we get the police involved, we'll be playing right into the protesters' hands.

idioms.text: put your hand in your pocket
idioms.sense: to spend money or give it to somebody
examples: I've heard he doesn't like putting his hand in his pocket.

idioms.sense: easily controlled or influenced by another person
examples: She'll persuade him. He's like putty in her hands.

idioms.sense: to hit or threaten to hit somebody
a person that you can trust to do a job well
examples: Colleagues regard him as a safe pair of hands.

idioms.sense: by being told about something by somebody else who has seen it or heard about it, not by experiencing, seeing, etc. it yourself
examples: I'm fed up of hearing about these decisions third hand!

idioms.text: show your hand/cards (North American English also tip your hand)
idioms.sense: to make your plans or intentions known
a way of voting for or against something in which people raise their hands to vote
examples: The vote was passed by a show of hands.
Let’s have a show of hands. Who’s in favour of the proposal?

idioms.sense: to stop yourself from doing something; to prevent you from doing something
examples: It was prudence, not logic, that stayed his hand.

idioms.text: take your courage in both hands
idioms.sense: to make yourself do something that you are afraid of
examples: Taking her courage in both hands, she opened the door and walked in.

idioms.sense: to deal with somebody in a strict way in order to improve their behaviour

idioms.text: take something into your own hands
idioms.sense: to deal with a particular situation yourself because you are not happy with the way that others are dealing with it

idioms.text: take the law into your own hands
idioms.sense: to do something illegal in order to punish somebody for doing something wrong, instead of letting the police deal with them
examples: After a series of burglaries in the area, the police are worried that residents might take the law into their own hands.
When police failed to arrest the suspect, local people took the law into their own hands and beat him up.

idioms.text: take your life in your hands
idioms.sense: to risk being killed
examples: You take your life in your hands just crossing the road here.

idioms.sense: to stop doing something or taking part in something, especially because you are not successful
to raise both hands in the air to show that you are feeling annoyed or upset about something
examples: We threw up our hands in despair at the scale of the problem.

idioms.sense: that you can reach or get easily
examples: I'm afraid I don't have the latest figures to hand.
Keep a pen and paper to hand for details of this week’s competition.

idioms.sense: to do something such as an activity or a sport for the first time
to start doing something or be able to do something, especially when you do it well
examples: Jim can turn his hand to most jobs around the house.

idioms.text: wait on somebody hand and foot
idioms.sense: to take care of somebody’s needs so well that they do not have to do anything for themselves
examples: He seems to expect me to wait on him hand and foot.

idioms.sense: to refuse to be responsible for or involved with somebody/something
examples: When her son was arrested again she washed her hands of him.
I’ve washed my hands of the whole sordid business.

idioms.sense: to win something very easily
to press somebody’s hand very hard when you shake hands
to hold your hands together, and twist and press them together in a way that shows you are anxious or upset, especially when you cannot change the situation

senses.text: the part of the body on top of the neck containing the eyes, nose, mouth and brain
examples: She nodded her head in agreement.
He shook his head in disbelief.
The boys hung their heads in shame.
She turned her head to look at him.
They bowed their heads in prayer.
She tilted her head back and closed her eyes.
to raise/lift/lower your head
He was shot in the head and died ten minutes later.
The driver suffered head injuries.
He still has a good head of hair (= a lot of hair).
a woman with a beautiful head of chestnut hair
He lay writhing on the ground, clutching his head in pain.
He put his head around the door.
He put his head in his hands, exasperated.
He scratched his head, not understanding a word.
He shaved his head and became a monk.
He threw his head back and laughed out loud.
Her head tilted to one side as she considered the question.
His head drooped and tears fell into his lap.
I banged my head on the door frame.
I'm normally asleep as soon as my head hits the pillow.
She declined with a brief shake of the head.
She jerked her head in the direction of the door.
She rested her head on his shoulder.
She sat with bowed head.
The ambassador dismissed him with a curt nod of the head.
The city gates were adorned with severed heads.
The soldiers were ordered to fire over the heads of the crowd.
The thunder burst with a grand crash above our heads.
I sometimes wonder what goes on in that head of yours.
I wish you'd use your head (= think carefully before doing or saying something).
The thought never entered my head.
His head was spinning (= he felt dizzy or confused) after only one drink.
in somebody's head I can't work it out in my head—I need a calculator.
She started hearing voices in her head.
into somebody's head Who's been putting such weird ideas into your head (= making you believe that)?
out of somebody's head I can't get that tune out of my head.
Try to put the exams out of your head (= stop thinking about them).
It was the first name that popped into my head.
It was an accident, said a voice inside his head.
I decided to go for a walk to clear my head.
He looked at me as if I needed my head examined.
Don't bother your pretty little head with things like that!
It never entered my head that he might be lying.
She's a good head taller than her sister.
The favourite won by a short head (= a distance slightly less than the length of a horse's head).
I woke up with a really bad head this morning.
head of something the heads of government/state
She resigned as head of department.
I've asked the department head for an appointment.
a former head of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange
He is deputy head of the National Railway Museum.
the crowned heads (= the kings and queens) of Europe
I was head coach of a Little League basketball team in Pittsburgh.
the head gardener/chef/waiter
He is only the nominal head of the company.
The Queen is titular head of the Church of England.
The Bishop is head of the Church in Kenya.
I've been called in to see the Head.
the deputy head
I remember sitting outside the Head's office waiting to be called in.
She is deputy head of Greenlands Comprehensive, a struggling inner city school.
The minister has written to every secondary head in Scotland.
I called heads and it came down tails.
the head of a nail
at the head of the page
They finished the season at the head of their league.
The President sat at the head of the table.
The prince rode at the head of his regiment.
Remove the dead heads to encourage new growth.
200 head of sheep
The old engine still manages to build up a good head of steam.
to give head
I managed to get my head down for an hour.
That glass of wine has gone straight to my head.
to have a head for figures/business
He fell head first down the stairs.
She got divorced and rushed head first into another marriage.
A lot of the jokes went (= were) right over my head.
I couldn't help feeling jealous when she was promoted over my head.
I’m not happy that you went over my head to ask for this time off.

idioms.sense: to force people to stop arguing and behave in a sensible way

idioms.text: be banging, etc. your head against a brick wall
idioms.sense: to keep trying to do something that will never be successful
examples: Trying to reason with them was like banging my head against a brick wall.

idioms.text: be/stand head and shoulders above somebody/something
idioms.sense: to be much better than other people or things
examples: His performance stood head and shoulders above the rest.

idioms.sense: to shout at somebody in an angry way, especially without reason

idioms.text: bring something to a head | come to a head
idioms.sense: if you bring a situation to a head or if a situation comes to a head, you are forced to deal with it quickly because it suddenly becomes very bad
examples: The chairman's resignation finally brought matters to a head.
The dispute finally came to a head in March that year.
Things came to a head when several of the nurses made a formal complaint.

idioms.text: bury/hide your head in the sand
idioms.sense: to refuse to admit that a problem exists or refuse to deal with it

idioms.text: can’t make head nor/or tail of something
idioms.sense: to be unable to understand something
examples: I couldn't make head nor tail of what he was saying.

idioms.sense: to make somebody feel confused, upset and/or annoyed
examples: Shut up! You're doing my head in.

idioms.text: do something standing on your head
idioms.sense: to be able to do something very easily and without having to think too much

idioms.text: drum something into somebody’s head (also drum something into somebody)
idioms.sense: to make somebody remember something by repeating it a lot of times
covering your whole body
examples: We were covered from head to foot in mud.
She was dressed from head to toe in red.

idioms.sense: to sleepto avoid attracting attention to yourself
examples: I managed to get my head down for an hour.

idioms.sense: to be able to understand or accept something
examples: She's dead. I can't get my head round it yet.

idioms.sense: to start to understand or think something
examples: When will you get it into your head that I don't want to discuss this any more!
For some reason she's got it into her head that I don't like her.

idioms.sense: to allow somebody to do what they want without trying to stop them

idioms.text: give somebody ideas | put ideas into somebody’s head
idioms.sense: to give somebody hopes about something that may not be possible or likely; to make somebody act or think in an unreasonable way
examples: Who's been putting ideas into his head?

idioms.sense: to deal with somebody in a very direct and determined way
examples: The company will be going head to head with the giant of the pharmaceuticals market.

idioms.sense: to make you feel drunkto make you feel too proud of yourself in a way that other people find annoying
examples: That glass of wine has gone straight to my head.

idioms.text: have eyes in the back of your head
idioms.sense: to be aware of everything that is happening around you, even things that seem difficult or impossible to see
examples: You can’t get away with anything in her class. She has eyes in the back of her head.

idioms.text: have a good head on your shoulders
idioms.sense: to be a sensible person
to be good at somethingif somebody does not have a head for heights, they feel nervous and think they are going to fall when they look down from a high place
examples: to have a head for figures/business

idioms.text: have your head/nose in a book
idioms.sense: to be reading
examples: She always has her nose in a book.

idioms.text: have your head in the clouds
idioms.sense: to be thinking about something that is not connected with what you are doingto have ideas, plans, etc. that are not realistic

idioms.text: have your head screwed on (the right way)
idioms.sense: to be a sensible person

idioms.text: have a roof over your head
idioms.sense: to have somewhere to live
examples: Thanks to Bob’s generosity, I still have a roof over my head.

idioms.sense: for each person
examples: The meal worked out at $20 a head.

idioms.sense: moving forwards or downwards with your head in front of the rest of your bodywithout thinking carefully about something before acting
examples: He fell head first down the stairs.
She got divorced and rushed head first into another marriage.

idioms.text: your head is spinning | make your head spin
idioms.sense: your head feels as though it is going round and round and you cannot balance, especially because you are ill or confused or have had a shock; to make you feel like this
examples: Her head was spinning from the pain.
His theories on economics are enough to make your head spin.

idioms.sense: loving somebody very much
examples: He's fallen head over heels in love with his boss.

idioms.sense: used to ask somebody which side of a coin they think will be facing upwards when it is tossed in order to decide something by chance
used to say that some people will be punished because of something that has happened

idioms.text: hit the nail on the head
idioms.sense: to say something that is exactly right

idioms.text: hold/put a gun to somebody’s head
idioms.sense: to force somebody to do something that they do not want to do, by making threats

idioms.text: hold your head high | hold up your head
idioms.sense: to be proud of or not feel ashamed about something that you have done
examples: She managed to hold her head high and ignore what people were saying.

idioms.sense: used to threaten somebody that you will hit them
involved in something that is too difficult for you to deal with
examples: After a week in the new job, I soon realized that I was in over my head.

idioms.text: keep your head | keep a clear/cool head
idioms.sense: to remain calm in a difficult situation
examples: She needed to keep a clear head if she was to remain in control.

idioms.sense: to deal with a difficult situation, especially one in which you have financial problems, and just manage to survive
examples: I’m not sure how much longer we’ll be able to keep our heads above water.

idioms.sense: to avoid attracting attention to yourself
examples: If I were you, I’d keep your head down for a couple of weeks.

idioms.sense: to laugh very loudly and for a long time

idioms.text: laugh, scream, etc. your head off
idioms.sense: to laugh, etc. a lot and very loudly

idioms.text: let your heart rule your head
idioms.sense: to act according to what you feel rather than to what you think is sensible

idioms.text: like a bear with a sore head
idioms.sense: in a bad mood; in an angry way
examples: I should keep out of his way. He’s like a bear with a sore head this morning.

idioms.sense: to become unable to act in a calm or sensible way
to be crazy

idioms.text: not bother yourself/your head with/about something
idioms.sense: to not spend time/effort on something, because it is not important or you are not interested in it

idioms.text: not harm/touch a hair of somebody’s head
idioms.sense: to not hurt somebody physically in any way

idioms.text: off the top of your head
idioms.sense: just guessing or using your memory, without taking time to think carefully or check the facts
examples: I can't remember the name off the top of my head, but I can look it up for you.

idioms.text: (have) an old head on young shoulders
idioms.sense: used to describe a young person who acts in a more sensible way than you would expect for a person of their age
used to tell somebody that they will have to accept any unpleasant results of something that they decide to do
examples: Tell him the truth if you want to, but on your own head be it!

idioms.text: out of/off your head (British English, informal)
idioms.sense: crazynot knowing what you are saying or doing because of the effects of alcohol or drugs
too difficult or complicated for somebody to understandto a higher position of authority than somebody
examples: A lot of the jokes went (= were) right over my head.
I couldn't help feeling jealous when she was promoted over my head.
I’m not happy that you went over my head to ask for this time off.

idioms.sense: an amount of money that is offered for capturing or killing somebody
examples: Ever since he killed the gang’s leader, there has been a price on his head.

idioms.text: put/lay your head/neck on the block
idioms.sense: to risk losing your job, damaging your reputation, etc. by doing or saying something
examples: It's not a matter that I'm prepared to put my head on the block for.

idioms.sense: to think about or discuss something as a group
if something unpleasant rears its head or rears its ugly head, it appears or happens
to make you feel that you can still hear something
examples: His warning was still ringing in my ears.

idioms.sense: to think hard in order to find an answer to something
examples: Experts have been scratching their heads over the increase in teenage crime.

idioms.sense: to make people think about something in a completely different way
to be remembered for a long time
examples: One of his paintings in particular sticks in my mind.

idioms.text: take it into your head that…
idioms.sense: to suddenly start thinking something, especially something that other people think is stupid

idioms.text: take it into your head to do something
idioms.sense: to suddenly decide to do something, especially something that other people think is stupid
a physical condition in which your head is painful or you cannot think clearly as a result of an illness or of drinking too much alcohol
examples: You’re going to have a thick head in the morning!

idioms.sense: to make a person feel too proud in a way that other people find annoying

idioms.text: two heads are better than one
idioms.sense: used to say that two people can achieve more than one person working alone

idioms.text: use your head (British English also use your loaf)
idioms.sense: used to tell somebody to think about something, especially when they have asked for your opinion or said something stupid
examples: ‘Why don't you want to see him again?’ ‘Oh, use your head!’

idioms.sense: to dislike somebody because of something bad they have done to you in the past
examples: I don’t have anything against her, we just don’t get along.

idioms.sense: to finish something unpleasant so that it does not continue
examples: Let's have done with this silly argument.

idioms.sense: to be in a very bad condition; to be unable to be repairedto be extremely tiredto have lost all chance of surviving somethingto be going to experience something unpleasantto be unable to accept a situation any longer
examples: The car had had it.
I've had it! I'm going to bed.
When the truck smashed into me, I thought I'd had it.
Dad saw you scratch the car—you've had it now!
I’ve had it (up to here) with him—he’s done it once too often.

idioms.sense: to claim that it is a fact that…
examples: Rumour has it that we'll have a new manager soon.

idioms.sense: to be likely to suffer the unpleasant effects of your actions and to deserve to do so
examples: It was no surprise when she left him—everyone knew he had it coming to him.

idioms.sense: to not like somebody and be unpleasant to them

idioms.text: have it in you (to do something)
idioms.sense: to be capable of doing something
examples: Everyone thinks he has it in him to produce a literary classic.
You were great. I didn't know you had it in you.
You spoke really well at that meeting, standing up for us all. I never knew you had it in you.

idioms.sense: to have sex with somebody
to be not nearly as good as somebody/something
not willing to listen to or believe something
examples: I tried to persuade her to wait but she wasn't having any.

idioms.sense: other things, people, etc. of the same kind
examples: There's room in the cellar to store old furniture and what have you.
